text.p: Organon, a pharmaceuticals unit of Dutch chemicals group Akzo Nobel, said on Tuesday it will further reorganise its research activities in the Netherlands, Scotland and France.

Akzo said it will close Organon's research unit in Riom, France as it had become too small, but would strengthen its research programmes in the Netherlands and Scotland, thus achieving more efficient use of resources, the firm said.
Organon would shed 30-40 research jobs in France, but overall staff numbers were not expected to fall. "They're more likely to rise," Akzo Nobel said.

"New technologies and research methods, such as 'combinatorial chemistry', gene-therapy and robotisation offer opportunities for new and better pharmaceuticals. But this requires large investments...both at Organon and specialised outside companies", Akzo said in a statement.
Akzo will strengthen its Scottish research by concentrating research of all its psychotherapeutic treatments, leading to a significant increase in staff there.
In its Oss-headquarters in the Netherlands, Organon will bundle its research in the fields of gynaecology, arthritis and thrombosis.
A number of the 60 employees in the field of psychosis working in the Netherlands will be offered jobs in Newhouse, Scotland, while others would be put on different projects, a spokeswoman said.
